<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of fill_v1_form:
```c
static enum MHD_Result
fill_v1_form (const void *cls,
              const char *mime,
              struct Session *session,
              struct MHD_Connection *connection)
{
  enum MHD_Result ret;
  size_t slen;
  char *reply;
  struct MHD_Response *response;
  (void) cls; /* Unused. Silent compiler warning. */

  slen = strlen (MAIN_PAGE) + strlen (session->value_1);
  reply = malloc (slen + 1);
  if (NULL == reply)
    return MHD_NO;
  snprintf (reply,
            slen + 1,
            MAIN_PAGE,
            session->value_1);
  /* return static form */
  response =
    MHD_create_response_from_buffer_with_free_callback (slen,
                                                        (void *) reply,
                                                        &free);
  if (NULL == response)
  {
    free (reply);
    return MHD_NO;
  }
  add_session_cookie (session, response);
  if (MHD_YES !=
      MHD_add_response_header (response,
                               MHD_HTTP_HEADER_CONTENT_ENCODING,
                               mime))
  {
    fprintf (stderr,
             "Failed to set content encoding header!\n");
  }
  ret = MHD_queue_response (connection,
                            MHD_HTTP_OK,
                            response);
  MHD_destroy_response (response);
  return ret;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
snprintf (reply,
            slen + 1,
            MAIN_PAGE,
            session->value_1);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 21.17 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: Not directly violated: snprintf is not a <string.h> function and, given MAIN_PAGE contains exactly one %s placeholder, the code allocates reply of length strlen(MAIN_PAGE)+strlen(session->value_1)+1 which is >= the formatted output length, so snprintf(..., slen+1, MAIN_PAGE, session->value_1) will not write beyond reply. However a real violation scenario exists if the format string and arguments do not match (for example MAIN_PAGE contains more or different conversion specifiers than the single %s): e.g. MAIN_PAGE = "...%s%s..." but only session->value_1 is passed — snprintf will read a bogus pointer for the second %s and may read beyond the bounds of that object (or cause other undefined behaviour). Also if session->value_1 is not NUL-terminated, strlen(session->value_1) invokes out-of-bounds access before allocation.
